def.caption: n-tuple of numbers
def.para:

An expression of the form (x_1,\dots ,x_n), where x_1,\dots ,x_n are numbers.

li.para:
The symbol x_1 represents a number, called the first coordinate
coordinate of an n-tuple
Example for n=3: (5,1,2) is a 3-tuple; i.e. it has 3 positions, each of which is occupied by a number. These numbers are the coordinates of the 3-tuple. Thus the first coordinate is 5. The second coordinate is 1. The third coordinate is 2.
of the n-tuple.
The symbol x_2 represents a number, called the second coordinate of the n-tuple.
In general, if 1\leq i\leq n is an integer, then the i-th coordinate of (x_1,\dots ,x_n) is the number x_i in the i-th position.

def.caption: Equal n-tuples
def.para:
Two n-tuples (x_1,\dots ,x_n) and (y_1,\dots ,y_n) are equal if and only if, for each 1\leq k\leq n, x_k=y_k.

def.caption: The set \RNr[n]

info.caption: Explanation: How to Read this
info.para: R n is defined to be the set of all n-tuples (x_1,\dots ,x_n) such that x_1,\dots, x_n are in \RNr.

info.caption: Explanation: on the Meaning of this Definition
info.para: Thus, each n-tuple forms a single element in \RNr[n]. The collection of all such n-tuples forms the space \RNr[n].

def.para:
For a positive integer n, the space \RNr[n] is the set of all n-tuples of numbers; in symbols
\RNr[n]
Consists of the collection of all n-tuples (x_1,\dots ,x_n) of numbers.

subsection.body.para: If n is 4 or greater, then \RNr[n] is not accessible to our visual sense. However, we can still (abstractly) imagine a space in which a point \Vect{0} has been designated as the origin, and in which n orthogonal lines through \Vect{0} have been chosen together with a unit of measurement.

The number n is called the dimension of \RNr[n]. It counts how many
independent directions
How do we find directions of motion in \RNr[n]?
At any given point in \RNr[n] we can run in the direction given by any one of the coordinate axes.
These directions of motion are independent from one another because it is impossible to combine any one of them from motions in the remaining ones.
There are no more independent directions of motion, as each direction of motion in \RNr[n] can be combined from suitable motions in the various coordinate directions.
of freedom of motion the space of all n-tuples of numbers in \RNr has.
It is convenient to define the space \RNr[0] to consist solely of the origin \Vect{0}=(0). This is consistent with the idea that a 0-dimensional space should not permit any movement.
